title: Analysis of Dante's Concept of Predestination in "La Divina Commedia"
first_phrase: This text explores the concept of predestination and purification necessary for knights to attain the Holy Grail. It touches on Dante's journey through hell and purgatory, where he is prevented from ascending by a lion and a she-wolf, which symbolize a degraded form of secular and spiritual authority. Though Dante's Christian beliefs limit his understanding, his journey can be seen as a reflection of the hero's journey. This last part delves deeper into the interpretation of the symbols of the wold, lion and gigant, and their relation to principles of realeza and authority.
content: La interpretación más corriente, según la cual la loba y la prostituta representan a la Iglesia católica, mientras que el león y el gigante simbolizan la Casa de Francia, nos parece también la justa; sólo que va un paso más allá quien, de la referencia histórica contingente (que entonces afectaba al episodio de la destrucción de la Orden de los Templarios) se remonta a los correspondientes principios. León y gigante se nos aparecen entonces, más en general, como representaciones del principio de una realeza degradada, laica, prevaricadora, del salvaje principio guerrero; mientras que la loba y la prostituta se referirán a una involución o degradación correspondiente sobrevenida al principio de la autoridad espiritual. Sin embargo, por lo que se refiere a este segundo punto, la concepción de Dante sufre de una limitación derivada de su adhesión al cristianismo.
last_phrase: In conclusion, Dante's use of symbols in his work suggests a degradation of both the secular and spiritual principles that guided society during his time. While his criticism of the corrupt Catholic Church is valid, his adherence to Christianity limits his perspective on what constitutes a truly traditional reconstruction. Nonetheless, Dante holds onto hope for a leader, the "Veltro", who will end the prevalence of corruption and restore order to society.
